sections.title: Economic Growth
sections.description: According to Bureau of Economic Analysis (2023), Houston's GDP was $1.6 trillion, marking a growth rate of 2.5% from the previous year. This growth was primarily driven by the energy, manufacturing, and healthcare sectors.

sections.title: Wealth Demographics
sections.description: According to U.S. Census Bureau American Community Survey (2023), the median income in Houston is $51,203. The city's wealth distribution shows a significant proportion of households earning between $50,000 and $75,000 annually, indicating a strong middle-class presence.

sections.title: Advisor Specializations
sections.description: Based on Bureau of Labor Statistics (2024), the healthcare and energy sectors are the largest employers in Houston. Therefore, financial advisors specializing in these industries may find ample opportunities.

sections.title: Cost of Living
sections.description: According to Bureau of Labor Statistics (2024), the Consumer Price Index for Houston increased by 1.8% over the previous year, indicating a moderate rise in the cost of living.

sections.title: Real Estate Market
sections.description: According to Zillow (2024), the median home value in Houston is $305,000, showing a 4.5% increase from the previous year. The market is considered to be 'hot', with high demand and limited supply.

sections.title: Business Environment
sections.description: According to Fortune 500 (2024), Houston is home to 22 Fortune 500 companies, including Phillips 66, Sysco, and ConocoPhillips. This concentration of large corporations provides a robust business environment and employment opportunities.
